svg.content: <mxfile host="Electron" modified="2020-03-31T09:52:25.276Z" agent="Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_12_6) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) draw.io/12.6.5 Chrome/80.0.3987.86 Electron/8.0.0 Safari/537.36" etag="_XqccmZNayRkjf4Jy2_u" version="12.6.5" type="device"><diagram id="LQBaBADTUmdg7iCwfanJ" name="Page-1"></diagram></mxfile>

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 38px; height: 1px; padding-top: 271px; margin-left: 31px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 38px; height: 1px; padding-top: 271px; margin-left: 151px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 468px; height: 1px; padding-top: 391px; margin-left: 281px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div:
With outward growth from the origin of two different shapes, we can model an oversimplified version of the idea of government, where the boundary is limits from regulation.
Resources are evenly distributed in the circle as all growth is equivalent in speed, varying in direction, and is enforced by a circular boundary or is enforced in the inputs by hard-coding the direction difference & keeping speed constant.
In the square, the regulation leaves gaps between evenly distributed growth and enforcement, so whichever agents get to the gaps first can expand rapidly & take up the exploits, shortcuts, & other loopholes to grow faster or fill the space. This situation produces:
- incentivized corners
- optimal paths to get to the corners first
- ability to replace the growth/shape of other agents that occupy other corners
How do you produce even distribution, from a system with built-in structural exploits in the difference between target behavior and incentivized behavior (corners)?
1. If you insert variance at points in the optimal paths, you can prevent the agents growing in those directions from reaching the corners first, but that wouldn't create even distribution unless it was carefully regulated.Â
2. Switching the corner agents' position/resources regularly might create even distribution if it was carefully executed & maintained, so whoever occupies the corners first is always swapped out, so no agent achieves power every time, introducing some randomness to the process. However if optimal path information is stored, they can use those paths to get to the corner again in subsequent attempts. This removes the incentive for faster than average growth, but then the population may not develop the functions to navigate the corner spaces, which are different and may be useful in other contexts. The cost is a possible lack of flexibility, if everyone has the same incentives & other resources. The corner-emerging functions may help with other problems than even distribution, like organization.
